cip.render.raytrace.camera

Class Aperture

  • java.lang.Object
    • cip.render.raytrace.camera.ACamera
      • cip.render.raytrace.camera.Aperture
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    IDynXmlObject, INamedObject, IRtCamera

    public class Aperture
extends ACamera
    This is The implementation of a perspective camera focused through a lens with variable aperture. The aperture camera is a camera in which the lens is an area lens, modeled as a roughly square area parallel to the target plane. This camera will simulate depth-of-field using distributed ray techniques.

    The area camera is specified as a node in an XML file as:

        <DynamicallyLoadedObject class="cip.raytrace.camera.Aperture" name="cameraName">
          <position Xfm4x4f_attributes/>
          <targetWidth>width</targetWidth>
          <targetDist>distance</targetDist>
          <lensDiameter>diameter</lensDiameter>
        </DynamicallyLoadedObject>

     The elements are optional and are applied in the order specified. For example if you specify a target distance, but then specify the camera position by origin and aimed at - the target distance will be adjusted to be the distance between the origin and the aimed at. Conversly, if you specify the position first and then the distance, the camera position and orientation is preserved and the target point is moved to the distance specified from the eye position. If you specify camera position more than once, the last position will override the earlier positions.

    where:
    postion The camera position and orientation as specified by the Xfm4x4f_attributes which are described in Xfm4x4f.setValue(Element, boolean, boolean). The most common methods of specification are originAt and aimedAt or originAt and aximuth, altitude orientation. If originAt is set, this becomes the camera location. If aimedAt is set, this becomes the parget point.
    targetWidth The target plane width.
    targetDist The distance from the parget point to the camera. If the camera position has been previously set, then it is maintained and the target point is moved to meet the specified target distance. If the camera position has not previously been set, the target point is maintained and the camera is moved to meet the specified target distance.
    lensDiameter or aperture The diameter of the lens. The default is a lens diameter of 0.5. As in real life, depth-of-field (the range of distance that the image is in focus) is inversely proportional to the diameter of the lens. The larger the lens, the smaller the depth-of-field, the smaller the lens, the larger the depth-of-field. The image plane (target plane) is where the camera is focused.

    Example of XML Specification

    The following specifies a pinhole camera with the camera location and target point specified in the position, and a target plane width of 6:

        <DynamicallyLoadedObject class="cip.raytrace.camera.Aperture" name="camera">
          <position originAt="5.0,-5.0,5.0" aimedAt="1.0f,-1.0f,-0.5f"/>
          <targetWidth>6</targetWidth>
          <lensDiameter>.5</lensDiameter>
        </DynamicallyLoadedObject>

    Since:
    1.0

      • loadFromXml

        public void loadFromXml(@NotNull
                        @NotNull org.w3c.dom.Element xmlElement,
                        @Nullable
                        @Nullable java.util.LinkedList refObjectList)
                 throws DynXmlObjParseException
        Description copied from interface: IDynXmlObject
        Loads this object from an XML DOM Document element. The DynXmlObjLoader has parsed the element and attributes to determine that this is a dynamically loaded object, found and instantiated the class, and is now sending the node to the object so it can initialize itself based on the contents of the node.
        Parameters:
        xmlElement - The dynamically loaded object DOM Document element.
        refObjectList - A linked list if named objects (implementing the INamedObject interface) that have already been loaded and can be used to resolve object references.
        Throws:
        DynXmlObjParseException - Thrown if there was an error parsing the object. If this exception is thrown it should be assumed that this object was incorrectly initialized, is invalid, and should not be used in any further operations.

      • getRay

        public void getRay(Line3f ray,
                   RayIntersection rayIntersection,
                   int nXpixel,
                   int nYpixel,
                   int nSample,
                   int nRandom)
        Description copied from interface: IRtCamera
        Performs the mapping from a pixel and pixel sub-sample to a ray. The upper left corner of the picture plane is taken as 0,0. If the rayIntersection is non-null, then the view vector and sampling information (sample start offset and sample solid angle) will be set in the ray intersection
        Specified by:
        getRay in interface IRtCamera
        Overrides:
        getRay in class ACamera
        Parameters:
        ray - The ray that will be computed as the mapping from the specified pixel and subsample.
        rayIntersection - The ray intersection to be initialized (if non-null).
        nXpixel - The pixel X location.
        nYpixel - The pixel Y location.
        nSample - The pixel sub-sample.
        nRandom - The random value for this sub-sample..
